Welcome to Concussion Coach, a mobile companion for Veterans and Service members who have had an injury to their brain. To make it easy to use this app, the word concussion will be used for all types of brain injury.

Concussion Coach does not replace professional treatment. Let your healthcare provider know if you are using Concussion Coach. If your symptoms concern you and your family, please seek medical attention.

To customize this app, please answer the following. You can always reset this information by tapping the Settings button on the home screen.

Have you ever experienced a concussion?

If you have been diagnosed with a concussion, the tools on this app may help you manage your symptoms. However, this app is not intended to replace working with a healthcare provider.

If you are currently in treatment for your concussion symptoms, it is important to talk with your provider about using this app. The app along with medical care can help you manage your symptoms.

Go to the Home screen to begin using the app.

Even if you did not have a concussion you can benefit from this app. The information and tools in this app may help you deal with symptoms that can occur for a variety of reasons.

Go to the Home screen to begin using the app.

Only a trained healthcare professional can determine if you had a concussion. However, the concussion screening on this app may help you decide if you should get an evaluation from a professional.

If you suspect that you had a concussion, talk with your doctor. He or she can help figure out if your symptoms are due to concussion or to other conditions.

Tap "Screen me" to get some more information.

Did you experience a physically powerful force to your head in which:

You were disoriented and confused afterward (to the point of not knowing where you were or what happened), but for less than a full day? You were disoriented and confused afterward, lasting for more than a full day?

Did you experience a physically powerful force to your head in which:

You have memory gaps for what happened afterward, but can remember the next day OK? You have memory gaps for what happened afterward, that lasted for more than a full day?

Did you experience a physically powerful force to your head in which:

You were knocked unconscious (totally unresponsive, unable to move on your own, eyes closed) for 30 minutes or less? You were knocked unconscious for more than 30 minutes?
Based on your answers, you likely did not have a concussion. However, the information and tools in this app may help you deal with symptoms that can occur for a variety of reasons.

This app was designed for people who had less severe concussion, but you may still find parts of it helpful.

Immediately after this event (within two days) did you experience:

Headaches, different from the headaches you may have had before? Nausea, with or without vomiting? Difficulty falling or staying asleep, different from your normal sleep pattern? Concentration or thinking difficulties, different from your prior pattern? Memory problems or forgetfulness, different from your prior pattern? Concussion Coach is a mobile phone application for Veterans, Service members, and others who have experienced a concussion or mild brain injury.

This application provides:

  • Education about concussions
  • A self-assessment instrument
  • Tools for managing problems associated with concussions
  • Direct connection to a crisis support line
  • Information about treatment by concussion professionals

Concussion Coach is intended to supplement face-to-face care with healthcare professionals. You can also use this application on its own, but it is not intended to replace medical treatment, professional diagnosis, or rehabilitation therapies for those who need them.

Content.title: Concussions
Content.Content:
What is a concussion?

The term "concussion" is used to describe a mild traumatic brain injury, but can also be used to describe brain injuries of all severities. The concussion causes a temporary disruption of brain function that manifests as:

  • Loss of consciousness for no longer than 30 minutes,
  • Loss of memory for events immediately before or after the injury,
  • Confusion or disorientation for no longer than 1 day, and
  • Dizziness or balance problems.

Did I have a concussion?

Only a trained healthcare professional can determine if you had a concussion. However, the concussion screening in the Settings section of this app may help you decide if you should get an evaluation from a professional.

When is concussion more serious?

When someone loses consciousness for more than 30 minutes or is disoriented for longer than 1 day after a head injury, the initial injury is likely more serious. In the same way, if something penetrates the skull, such as a bullet, then the injury is considered more severe.

People can have a wide range and severity of symptoms whether they've had a mild, moderate, or severe head injury. Symptoms from these injuries can be helped with this app.

How does concussion happen?

Concussion can come from:

  • The head being struck by an object, such as a bat or a fist during a fight,
  • The head striking an object, such as the dashboard in a car accident or the ground in a fall, or
  • The head being affected by a nearby blast or explosion.

What are concussion symptoms?

Symptoms from concussion can include:

  • Physical: Headaches, sleep difficulties, sensitivity to light or noise, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, balance problems, blurred vision, or feeling very tired.
  • Cognitive: Problems paying attention, concentrating, remembering, or processing information.
  • Emotional: Anxiety, irritability, or depression.

Is it concussion or another condition?

A number of other conditions can bring about some of the same symptoms as concussion. Witnessing traumatic events such as seeing someone severely injured or killed can result in similar symptoms. Preexisting pain, headaches, poor sleep, anxiety, stress, alcohol or substance abuse, and other conditions can also result in similar symptoms.

Speaking to a provider can help determine where the symptoms came from.

How long do symptoms last?

Symptoms of concussion often get better within 1 to 4 weeks. People who continue to have difficulties can usually be helped by a variety of health care professionals and self-help tools like this app.

Other conditions can affect recovery from concussion. For example, symptoms are likely to last longer if the injury happened during a psychologically traumatic event or to someone who was already stressed about personal problems. Fortunately, even symptoms made worse by other conditions can be improved with medical care and with using this app.

Managing symptoms after concussion

Effective treatments for concussion symptoms are available. You don't have to live with your symptoms forever. The most important thing you can do to recover after concussion is to pace yourself, get the rest you need, and get moving on the road to wellness.

If you've been diagnosed with a concussion, the tools on this app may help you manage your symptoms.

Symptoms and stress

Symptoms are your body's way of giving you information. Thinking and worrying about your symptoms can make them seem worse. This is partly because paying too much attention to a problem may make it seem bigger than it is.

Doing things you enjoy, are relaxing, and give you a sense of accomplishment will prevent you from over-focusing on your symptoms. After a concussion, it can be easy to forget that we all have times when we feel irritable, tired, have headaches, cannot concentrate, and are forgetful.

Content.title: Treatment for Concussion
Content.Content:
Learning about symptoms

Learning about the concussion symptoms and how to manage them is a powerful tool for recovery. Research has shown that learning about the effects of concussion and building positive expectations of recovery can help you get better faster and to a greater degree.

This app contains a lot of useful information about symptoms and how to manage them that can help you on your way to recovery.

Managing early symptoms

The most important treatment immediately after a concussion is rest. Pacing yourself, getting good sleep regularly, and even taking a few days off work or school are important steps to give the brain a chance to recover after a concussion.

Other treatments

Treatments for specific concussion symptoms may include:

  • Relaxation and stress management techniques
  • Pain medication for headaches, backaches, or neck pain
  • Suggestions for sleep hygiene
  • Organizing your environment and your schedule to help you remember things and reduce anxiety

Other interventions for managing ongoing symptoms can be found in the "Manage This Moment" section of this app.

Do I need professional help?

Whether or not you need help can only be determined by you and a trained healthcare professional. However, you can go and take the self-assessment on this app to see if you are scoring in the high, medium, or low range of symptoms. You can also ask yourself these questions. If you answer yes to any of them, then you might want to seek help.

  • Are your symptoms new, different or worse than they have typically been?
  • Are the usual medications, treatments or activities that have helped your symptoms no longer helping?
  • Have you noticed new or worsened functional difficulties?
  • Have you recently been hospitalized or had a new brain injury?
  • Do you have new questions or concerns about your brain injury, your symptoms, or your course of recovery?

If you said yes to any of these questions, you would likely benefit from talking with a healthcare professional. You don't have to wait for an emergency to get help.

Why do people usually seek professional care?

If concussion symptoms are significantly interfering with your daily life, one way to feel better and get back on track is to work with professionals who specialize in brain injury. They can help you learn to manage your symptoms, improve relationships with people in your life, pursue your goals, and focus on the future.

Healthcare professionals

In this section of the app, you can find the titles and brief descriptions of the roles of the healthcare professionals who often specialize in working with individuals with a concussion.

Seeing a physiatrist

A physiatrist is a rehabilitation physician who treats physical, cognitive, and behavioral symptoms of concussion. They can help plan a rehabilitation program that works for you and your family.

Seeing a neurologist

The initial goal of a neurological evaluation is to determine whether you had a concussion or whether your symptoms are caused by some other medical or mental health condition.

Seeing a psychiatrist

A psychiatrist can treat mental health symptoms of concussion by prescribing medication and providing therapy. There are many different changes in mood or behaviors that can result from concussion; a psychiatrist can help design a plan to treat these.

Seeing a psychologist

A neuropsychologist or psychologist can diagnose cognitive, emotional and behavioral symptoms of concussion. They may ask patients to undergo neuropsychological assessments that can help them and their families understand the nature and severity of deficits and can assist other treatment team members when planning treatment programs.

Seeing a neuro-opthalmologist

A neuro-ophthalmologist can help diagnose double vision, blurry vision and other visual deficits following brain injury. An audiologist evaluates hearing loss. Hearing changes after TBI may be include ringing in your ears or poor hearing, especially in noisy environments. Hearing aids may or may not be prescribed, depending upon the nature and severity of the problem.

Seeing an audiologist

An audiologist evaluates hearing loss. Hearing changes after a concussion may be include tinnitus or loss of hearing, especially in noisy environments. Hearing aids may or may not be prescribed, depending upon the nature and severity of the problem.

Seeing a speech pathologist

A speech-language pathologist evaluates and treats communication difficulties. These may include problems understanding directions and conversation, expressing ideas clearly, and communicating effectively with other people. The speech-language pathologist can also help select and train mobile devices and applications that support memory and attention skills required for everyday life tasks.

Seeing a physical therapist

A physical therapist assesses and treats balance disorders, dizziness, physical problems, and pain. Treatments aim to improve mobility, increase strength, decrease joint stiffness, improve balance, decrease vertigo and dizziness, and manage pain and discomfort. The physical therapist can also provide equipment, such as canes or braces, to improve safety and endurance of movement.

Seeing a kinesiotherapist

A kinesiotherapist can recommend a cardiovascular conditioning program that reduces the risk of injury or further disability. Fitness can have a positive impact upon people's mental and physical stamina, reduce pain, and enhance feelings of well-being. The physical conditioning program is often initiated in the health care facility and gradually transferred to a community gym.

Seeing an occupational therapist

An occupational therapist works with a person to improve their performance in daily routines. Treatment goals may include managing tasks in the community (shopping, driving, school and work activities) and improving daily self-care (feeding, dressing). To be able to do these tasks, patients may need to use special techniques, modify their physical environment or use equipment ranging from simple memory aids to more advanced technology such as computers.

Seeing a recreation therapist

A recreation therapist helps people participate in play and leisure activities, which enrich life. Through leisure counseling, leisure education, leisure skills development, aquatic education, adaptive sports, re-socialization programs and community outings, people can learn how to participate in community life more effectively.

Seeing a social worker

A social worker or counselor helps patients and their families deal with social, emotional or financial problems resulting from physical disability or chronic illness. Treatments include individual and group psychotherapy, crisis intervention, family counseling and family support groups. The social worker explores community resources and programs that are available to the patient and family.

Seeing a vocational counselor

A vocational rehabilitation counselor may act as a treatment coordinator for patients who are having difficulty returning to work. This specialist may provide assistance by collaborating with employers, patient and co-workers to build a successful working relationship.

Seeing a case manager

A case manager coordinates patient care. The case manager is an advocate and an active participant in the treatment process with the patient and their family.

Content.title: Cognition
Content.Content:
Cognitive problems

Cognitive problems are common immediately following a concussion. You may have difficulty concentrating on what you're doing and what others are saying (attention problems), you may be misplacing things and missing appointments (memory problems), and you may find it hard to think clearly and quickly.

Cognitive problems get better in the first few weeks and months after a concussion. When they continue for longer, cognitive problems may be affected by other health conditions or by stress. Check out "Manage This Moment" to learn about how to work on cognitive problems. See also "Use Technology" in the "Build Resilience" section to find out how you can use your device to help with cognitive problems.

Poor concentration

The main causes of poor concentration are being tired and worrying about things. If your mind if focused elsewhere, it is difficult to concentrate on the task at hand.

Improving concentration

To improve concentration, try the following:

  • Take a break at regular intervals: Even a 5 to 10 minute period of rest is helpful.
  • Limit the amount of distractions in your environment: Turn down the radio and the TV, work where it's quiet, organize your work space, and try not to do too many things at once.

The tools in the "Manage This Moment" section of this app provide ways to help you relax, so you can come back to what you were doing with improved concentration.

Memory problems

Poor concentration and being tired can affect memory. If you can't concentrate long enough, your brain does not have the time it needs to store the information and to remember it later. Concentration problems are a normal part of recovering from a concussion, and some memory trouble is a side effect of this.

Improve your memory

To improve your memory, try the following:

Get Enough Rest:

  • Memory problems can be a sign that you are pushing yourself too hard and trying to do too much. Taking breaks and getting a good night's sleep are very helpful.

Use Reminders:

  • Using the calendar and note functions on your smart phone, and organizing your home and work place are excellent ways of coping with memory difficulties. They will help your recovery and make your daily life easier.

Reduce Worries:

  • Worrying about remembering things can make your memory seem worse. If you can remember examples of memory slips you've experienced, you probably don't have a serious memory problem!

The tools in the "Manage This Moment" section of this app provide ways to help you improve your memory.

Trouble thinking

Problems with thinking clearly or quickly are usually the direct result of other symptoms. For example, poor concentration, being tired, headaches, and anxiety can all make it hard to think clearly.

Improve your thinking

To improve your thinking try the following:

Get enough rest:

  • Getting a good night's sleep is very important. Thinking difficulties can be a sign that you are trying to do too much or pushing yourself too hard.

Organize your daily schedule:

  • Keeping a schedule will help you accomplish what you need to get done.

Organize your thoughts:

  • To prepare for a meeting or conversation that may be difficult, write down your thoughts ahead of time and arrange them in order to help you say what you want to say most clearly.

Use reminders and technology tools:

  • Writing things down, and using the calendar and memo pad functions on your smart phone excellent ways of coping with temporary thinking difficulties. They will help your recovery and improve your daily functioning. There are more ideas for how to use your technology to improve your thinking in the Build Resilience section of this app.

What's normal?

18% of people who have never had a concussion have difficulties with concentration.

10% of people who have never had a concussion have difficulties with memory.

While identifying concussion symptoms is important, remember that some things are pretty common even in people without a concussion, and may be related more to stress or fatigue.

Content.title: Headaches
Content.Content:
What are PTHA?

Post-traumatic headaches (PTHA) are any new headaches or worsened headaches that start within 7 days of having a concussion.

Most PTHAs are the result of direct injury or trauma that strained the muscles covering the head and neck. Symptoms gradually improve as the muscle tissue heals.

Acute vs. chronic PTHA

Headaches will often get better in a week or so after concussion. Those that go away within 3 months of the injury are called "acute PTHA". If the headache symptoms last more than three months, they are called "chronic PTHA".

Acute PTHA affects 90% of people who have a concussion. Chronic PTHA is the most common pain problem after concussion.

Tension-type headaches

Tension-type headaches are the most common kind of headache. They affect 85% of those with PTHA. They're caused by tightness and injury to the skull muscles and feel like tightening or pressure at the temples or around the head, usually on both sides.

Migraine headaches

Migraine headaches are the second most common type of PTHA, affecting around 3% of people with PTHA. They're caused by spasms of small blood vessels around the skull. The pain is usually only on one side of the head and is often pulsating in nature. The pain is often associated with nausea, light-sensitivity, noise-sensitivity, or dizziness. These symptoms may occur before the pain begins (called "auras").

Rebound analgesic headaches

Rebound analgesic headaches are daily, dull, aching headaches that are caused by using lots of pain medications for a long time without carefully weaning off them.

Dull headaches with confusion

If you have a dull headache and gradually worsening sleepiness or confusion after a brain injury, this can be a sign of a slow level of bleeding in the skull (usually a "subdural hematoma"). You should see a doctor immediately if you have these symptoms.

Content.displayName: What should I tell my doctor?
Content.title: Headaches

Content.Content:
What should I tell my doctor?

When meeting with your clinician use the following word to remember what to say about your PTHA.

Think COLDER:

  • Characteristics
    • Intensity and frequency of the headache pain
    • Time of day the headache pain occurs
    • Other symptoms associated with the headache (nausea)
    • Presence of an aura (symptoms that occur before pain)
  • Onset (how do symptoms start, what brings them on)
  • Location (where in your head/neck are your symptoms)
  • Duration (how long the headache symptoms last)
  • Exacerbating factors (what makes symptoms worse)
  • Relieving factors (what makes symptoms better)

How to assess headache pain

While everyone describes headache pain in a slightly different way, we recommend using the same scale each time to assess your pain. We'll use a numeric scale to track your pain, where "0" mean no pain and "10" is the worst possible pain you can imagine. Make sure you record your headache pain level (as well as any changes in the "COLDER" symptom inventory) regularly in your wellness journal.

Medication for acute PTHA

Since almost all PTHA are short-lived, simply using over-the-counter pain medications (acetaminophen, aspirin, ibuprofen) or local heat (hot pack, heating pad) may be all that is needed for an acute headache. Clinicians can also prescribe stronger, prescription medications if pain is more severe.

Migraine headaches usually respond well to specific medications to prevent them from starting, as well as medications to shorten the symptoms. Ask your doctor about these medications.

Other treatments for PTHA

Other treatments for acute PTHA include:

  • Normalizing sleep patterns
  • Eating a balanced diet
  • Eliminating caffeine, alcohol and tobacco
  • Doing relaxation and meditation exercises
  • Seeking counseling for stress
  • Returning to a normal exercise routine

There are also special exercise activities for the muscles of the head and neck. You can get more information about these from your medical provider.

Medications for chronic PTHA

When PTHA lasts longer than 3 months, it is considered chronic. A brain injury (and headache) specialist should definitely be one of the medical providers you are seeing for care if you have chronic PTHA.

While specific medications for migraine headaches should continue to be used (and adjusted under the care of your doctor), the continued use of pain medications for chronic PTHA is not usually recommended. Common side effects of long-term narcotic pain medication usage can include addiction, constipation, lethargy and even worsened headaches (rebound analgesic headaches).

Problems related to chronic PTHA

Headaches may be symptoms of other problems such as depression, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, or alcohol, narcotic and substance abuse that can occur after concussion. Chronic headache pain can reduce one's ability to function in relationships, at work and school, and in leisure activities. In addition, people with PTHA may suffer physical symptoms and may be at increased risk of medical problems. If you are having ongoing physical or emotional symptoms related to PTHA, see your doctor.

I have PTHA, now what?

If you've been diagnosed with PTHA, the tools on this app may help you better manage your symptoms. However, this app is not intended or designed as a replacement for professional care. If you are currently in treatment for PTHA, it's important to talk with your provider about using this app.

What's normal?

24% of people who have never had a concussion experience headaches.

While identifying concussion symptoms is important, remember that some things are pretty common even in people without a concussion, and may be related more to stress or fatigue.

Sleep problems

Sleep problems include difficulty falling or staying asleep. Service members and Veterans are at especially high risk for sleep problems. Approximately 30% of Service members returning from combat deployment have difficulty sleeping.

Sleep problems can have a negative impact on almost all areas of your life, including your physical and mental health. Stomach discomfort, headaches, fatigue, irritability, and concentration problems are commonly reported by people with poor sleep.

Managing sleep

Two tools in this app in the "Manage This Moment" section specifically provide ways to help improve the quality of your sleep.

If you still continue to have problems after you practice using these tools, then you should consider seeking professional help from a brain injury specialist. A brain injury specialist might consider other options to help with your sleep, including medications or referral to a sleep specialist.

What's normal?

20% of people who have never had a concussion have trouble sleeping.

32% of people who have never had a concussion feel tired regularly.

While identifying concussion symptoms is important, remember that some things are pretty common even in people without a concussion, and may be related more to stress or fatigue.

What is sleep hygiene?

Sleep hygiene is a set of common sense rules that promote good sleep. These rules are scientifically proven techniques to help people fall asleep more quickly and to sleep more restfully.

Improve sleep environment

Distractions in the bedroom can interfere with falling asleep and staying asleep. Make sure your bedroom is comfortable, quiet, and free from distractions.

Don't exercise before bed

Exercising during the day can help you fall asleep more quickly, but exercising just before bedtime can make it harder to fall asleep. Schedule regular exercise in the morning, afternoon, or early evening. Try using the calendar on your phone to schedule a daily exercise time.

Limit caffeine and nicotine

Caffeine and nicotine are stimulants that can interfere with sleep. These drugs can remain in your body for hours. Limit your use of any product that contains stimulants (like soda, energy drinks, chocolate, and tobacco), especially in the afternoon or evening. Try not to drink coffee after lunchtime.

Use alcohol in moderation

Alcohol may help some people fall asleep, but it causes awakenings later in the night. Also, nighttime trips to the bathroom can interfere with sleep. Limit your use of any products containing alcohol and avoid using any alcohol in the hours right before bedtime.

Schedule a worry time

Worrying can interfere with falling asleep. Don't take your problems to bed with you. Schedule some time a few hours before bedtime to work through problems and plan the next day. Try setting a recurring alarm on your phone to remind you to set aside some time in the early evening to solve problems and plan you next day.

Sleep therapy

Sleep therapy is a scientifically proven technique that trains your body to fall asleep more quickly and to stay asleep through the night. The goal of sleep therapy is to make your body associate your bed only with sleep and falling asleep quickly. There are five important lessons to mastering sleep therapy.

Content.displayName: Go to bed only when sleepy
Content.title: Sleep Therapy

Content.Content:
Go to bed only when sleepy

Going to bed only when you are sleepy helps to ensure that you will fall asleep quickly, instead of lying in bed awake and feeling frustrated. You do not want your body and mind to associate the bed with the frustration of not falling asleep. Try going to bed only when you show signs of sleepiness, like yawning or having difficulty keeping your eyes open.

Out of bed if awake

Leave your bedroom if you can't fall asleep within 20 minutes. If you can't sleep, lying in bed for hours will cause you to associate your bed with being awake. Do something relaxing when you leave your bedroom, like reading or doing a crossword puzzle. Try using relaxation techniques when you go to bed or if you must leave your room after 20 minutes, try using the relaxation tools in the "Manage This Moment" section of this app.

Bedroom for two things only

Use your bedroom only for sleep and sexual activity. Using your bedroom only for sleep will help to train your brain and body to become sleepy whenever you enter the bedroom. Avoid activities like drinking, eating, exercising, reading, or watching television in or around your bed.

Wake up at the same time

Getting up at the same time each morning helps to set your daily biological clock. Staying in bed longer, even after a bad night of sleep, will make it harder to fall asleep at night. Set a recurring alarm on your phone to wake you up at the same time all seven days of the week.

Avoid napping

Avoiding napping during the day will help you to fall asleep more quickly at night. Even if you have a bad night of sleep, avoid napping and use your feeling of tiredness to fall asleep more quickly the next night.

Content.title: Anxiety & PTSD
Content.Content:
Anxiety

Anxiety is excessive worry about events or life situations. Anxiety becomes an issue when it interferes with the things you want to do. Symptoms of anxiety may come on suddenly or they may feel like they are always there in your life.

After a concussion you may feel anxious about any number of things, specific or general. For example you could be worried about "failing" at a task, being in crowds, or having to adjust to sudden changes.

Symptoms of anxiety

Nearly everyone feels anxiety after a trauma, but in most cases the symptoms gradually disappear. The most common anxiety symptoms after concussion are:

  • Being fearful
  • Intense worry
  • Feeling uneasy
  • Avoiding friends or family
  • Feeling irritable
  • Having nightmares
  • Having difficulty concentrating
  • Feeling restless
  • Muscle tension
  • Feeling panicked

If these symptoms are persistent or severe, then it's important to be evaluated by a healthcare provider.

Causes of anxiety after concussion

Following an injury it is normal to feel a great deal of stress. Stress can build up over time and can lead to anxiety. Anxiety can also occur if you experience too many demands by going back to work too soon after injury. You may have difficulties in situations that require a lot of attention and information-processing, which can make anxiety worse.

Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a specific kind of anxiety that is frequently associated with injuries or other traumatic experiences.

People with PTSD may:

  • Relive a traumatic event through flashbacks or nightmares, where the event seems to be happening again and again;
  • Avoid people or situations that remind them of the event or avoid having close relationships with others;
  • Feel numb or detached from other people or from stressful situations; and
  • Have difficulty concentrating, become easily startled or have outbursts of anger.

If you have been diagnosed with PTSD or you believe you may have PTSD, it's important to seek out and maintain a relationship with a healthcare provider who has experience treating this particular form of anxiety.

PTSD and concussion

The relationship between PTSD and concussion is hard to nail down and it requires a trained specialist to determine how they correlate in your case.

A person can have one of these problems or both at the same time. Having PTSD may make the symptoms of concussion harder to get past.

It can be stressful to hear that the problems you have been having since your concussion may actually be fueled in part by PTSD. Some people worry that this means the problem is "all in your head." However, decades of research on PTSD show that it is a real injury that can have serious effects on a person's life. Luckily, great treatments exist for PTSD that can help with this challenging disorder, with or without a concussion.

Treatments for anxiety

While it's possible that anxiety related to concussion can gradually go away over time, significant anxiety which interferes with your life requires some form of treatment.

Anxiety is usually treated with psychotherapy and medication. Several types of mental health professionals provide psychotherapy including counselors, social workers and psychologists. Physicians can evaluate your physical condition and prescribe medication. It is important to select a therapist you can talk to comfortably and honestly.

Content.title: Irritability
Content.Content:
Irritability

Frustration, irritability, and anger outbursts are behaviors that most of us experience in our lives regardless of whether or not we have had a concussion. However, these feelings can increase after a concussion. 1 in 3 people who have had a brain injury report increased irritability. Irritable responses can cause problems with your loved ones and people around you.

Causes of irritability

It is unclear what causes irritability following concussion. Injury to the brain can make people respond more intensely in different situations. Depression that may result from concussion can also make people more irritable. Irritability may cover for another emotion like grief, hurt, frustration or anxiety.

Content.displayName: What should I tell my doctor?
Content.title: Irritability

Content.Content:
What should I tell my doctor?

In order to best treat your irritability, there are several things to discuss with your clinician. These things include:

  • Irritability problems you had before the concussion,
  • Irritability problems you have since the concussion, and
  • Whether you have other mood-related difficulties, such as depression.

Describing my irritability

Use a numeric scale to keep track of your irritability, where "0" means no irritability and "10" is the worst possible irritability. Record your irritability level and what triggered it regularly in your wellness journal.

Content.displayName: What can I do about irritability?
Content.title: Irritability

Content.Content:
What can I do about irritability?

The majority of irritability associated with concussion will get better or go away completely within weeks after the injury. The tools on this app may help you better manage your symptoms.

However, this app is not intended or designed as a replacement for more traditional forms of psychological help. If irritability lasts longer than 3 months, you should see a mental health provider. If you are currently in treatment for irritability, it's important to talk with your provider about using this app.

Managing irritability

Tips for managing irritability:

  • Try to figure out the cause of irritability and address it if you can. Ask yourself: "Am I hungry? Am I upset about a relationship?" Finding the specific problem and considering solutions may reduce irritability.
  • Practice relaxation techniques like the ones in the "Manage This Moment" section of this app.
  • Take a time out. Remove yourself from the stressful situation. This allows for the opportunity to calm or cool down.

Problems related to irritability

Other problems such as depression, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety or alcohol, narcotic and substance abuse may occur with irritability. In fact, caffeine, alcohol and nicotine have all been shown to worsen irritability. Chronic irritability can reduce your ability to function in relationships, at work and school, and in leisure activities.

What's normal?

25% of people who have never had a concussion have difficulties with irritability.

While identifying concussion symptoms is important, remember that some things are pretty common even in people without a concussion, and may be related more to stress or fatigue.

Content.name: manage
Content.title: Tools
Content.Content:
People who have experienced a concussion have different experiences as they heal, but the problems below are common following a head trauma. You may experience none, some, or all of the following problems.

  • Thinking problems: You may notice slowing in your ability to think or process information.
  • Headache: You may develop headaches more frequently than before.
  • Anxiety: You may notice that you feel more uptight or get anxious more easily.
  • Irritability: You may notice that you are more short tempered or get angry more easily.
  • Sleep: You may notice that it is harder to fall asleep or stay asleep than before.

The tools in this app can help you manage these problems. Tap on a problem you currently have to be given practical things to do in the moment. If you like the tool, give it a thumbs up and it will appear on your favorites list in the future. If you don't like it, give it a thumbs down, and it will not come up again in the future.

Rate your distress on a scale of 0 (no distress at all) to 10 (the worst distress you could imagine).

This will help you monitor your distress levels and figure out which tools in this app work best for you.

You can rate your distress level — including stress, anger, physical tension or pain, and more, all rolled into one — on a scale of 0 to 10. This will help you monitor your distress levels and figure out which tools work best for you. You can also use it in your daily life to check in and see how you're doing.

It may seem strange at first, but sometimes we can get caught up in an all-or-nothing way of thinking — either I'm totally uncomfortable or I'm totally fine. The distress score can help you learn to see the shades of gray, and help you see that even when things aren't perfect, they may be improving. It can also help you learn to recognize what triggers distress for you.

Content.name: exercise

ExerciseCategory.name: ridCategory
ExerciseCategory.Content:
RID
The RID Tool is for times when you have been triggered by a reminder of a past trauma. You will be led through three steps to manage your distress.

When you're triggered or reminded of terrible things that have happened, your mind not only believes that you're in danger, your mind and your body act like you're right back in the traumatic situation. These lightning fast, automatic reactions are helpful at the time of the actual event because they keep you safe in dangerous situations. But now your automatic reactions to triggers are no longer helpful because in the 'here and now' you're not in any actual danger.

You use the RID tool to stay focused and cope with your triggers. Remember, triggers confuse your brain and your body into thinking that you're back in the original situation. You must clear away that confusion in order to manage your responses.

RID has three steps: The first step, the R in RID, is to Relax or calm yourself. The second step, the I in RID, is to Identify what's triggering you and how it's different from your original trauma. And the third step, the D in RID, is to Decide how to respond to the trigger. Doing these three things when you're triggered can be very helpful.

RID
Relax
Take 30 seconds to Relax by breathing in and out slowly. As you breathe in think the word "let," and as you breathe out think "go."
RID
Identify the Trigger

Go back over the last few minutes or hours and Identify what reminder of your trauma you encountered. Triggers can be internal, like thoughts or memories, or external, like conversations or situations or things we encounter in the world (e.g., a particular person or place). Figuring out what triggered you can be tricky sometimes. Do not worry if you cannot identify the trigger, just focus on relaxing and talking yourself down.

Once you identify the trigger if you can, it is important to remind yourself that it is just a reminder and not the actual trauma happening again, despite how your mind and body may be reacting. Really notice how the current trigger is different from your trauma. Remind yourself of those differences again and again.

Go on to fill in your triggers on the next screen.

RID
Identify the Trigger
What triggered you? How is your current situation different from the traumatic experience?
RID
Decide What to Do Now

The final step is to Decide what to do now. If you feel stressed now, you can try to decrease the trigger's power by deciding to stay in the situation — i.e. not try to avoid or escape that trigger. Most people quickly realise that they can handle it and that their stress will actually go down the longer they stick it out. If the trigger made you very angry, your best bet is to decide to take a time out. If you are in danger of hurting yourself or others, seek support and don't take any chances.

Go on to fill in your decision on the next screen.

RID
Decide What to Do Now
What will you decide to do?

ExerciseCategory.name: relaxationCategory
ExerciseCategory.Content:
Slowing down and deepening your breathing can help you calm down when you feel distress. Put on your headphones or go somewhere private and quiet to be led through the exercise. This activity will guide you through a brief exercise in which you take slower, deeper breaths to help you relax. Taking slow, deep breaths helps you balance the carbon dioxide and oxygen in your blood. This calms your nervous system, creating a "relaxation response." Deep breathing exercises can help manage stress and insomnia, focus the mind, and improve health.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
To prepare, get in a comfortable position - sitting would be best for now, so that you can practice as you listen and watch the demonstration. Later, when you practice, you can do this exercise sitting, standing up, or lying down - whatever works for you. Although this exercise should be safe for almost anyone, if you have difficulty breathing, or feel out of breath, or begin to feel dizzy, nervous, or out of control, you can adjust your breathing pace, or go back to breathing normally. The goal is just to slow down a bit to allow your system to relax. Place one hand on your belly, and one on your chest. Breathe in by taking air deep into your belly - allow your belly to expand out while your shoulders and chest stay relaxed. Now breathe out, slowly, allowing the air you exhale to deflate your belly. Pause naturally. Breathe in, taking air deep into your belly - allow your belly to expand; shoulders and chest stay relaxed. Now breathe out, slowly, but naturally. Breathe in, taking air deep into your belly. Think the number "1" Now exhale all of the air, and think the word "Relax". Breathe in, taking air deep into your belly, and think the number "2". Now exhale all of the air, and think the word "Relax". Breathe in - think the number "3". Now exhale - think the word "Relax" Breathe in. Think the number "4". Now breathe out, slowly - think the word "Relax". Breathe in. Five. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in. Six. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in. Seven. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in. Eight. Breathe out. Relax. Counting backwards now, breathe in. Eight. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in. Seven. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in slowly, deeply. Think the number Six. Breathe out slowly, all the way. Relax. Breathe in. Five. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in. Four. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in - Focus on your breath, and the number "3". Breathe out, all the way - Relax. Breathe in. Two. Breathe out. Relax. Breathe in, for the last time. Think the number "1", and breathe out. Relax. Good job. Even as you end this exercise, you can continue to allow your breathing to be deeper and slower - take your time as you open your eyes, and bring your attention back to your surroundings.

You are about to be led through a progressive muscle relaxation exercise. You will progress through each of your major muscle groups, tensing and relaxing as you go.This exercise takes about 9 minutes. It has audio, so you will need to find a quiet place or put on your headphones now. Sit down in a comfortable chair or lay down. Do not do this exercise while driving.

This exercise will guide you, either sitting comfortably or lying down, through tensing and relaxing a sequence of muscle groups. This allows muscles to relax more deeply than usual. This exercise can help decrease heart rate and blood pressure, slow breathing, decrease muscle tension, and clear thinking.

This exercise is also great because over time you can train yourself to really know what tense muscles feel like. Then, when you recognize that your muscles are tense or becoming tense, you can immediately switch your muscles to a more relaxed state because you have trained yourself to know how relaxed muscles feel.

Please note that if you have injuries such as back pain or a knee injury, you should avoid tensing muscles that might affect that injury. To begin, close your eyes, and take a deep breath into your belly. Then exhale with a sigh. Again, take a deep breath, and imagine clean air going down your throat, and filling your lungs, and then exhale with a sigh. Take another deep breath, and, as you release it, think the word "Relax", silently to yourself. Allow your breath to be slow and rhythmic, inhaling and exhaling at a pace that is comfortable for you. As you continue to breathe, continue to say the word "Relax" to yourself, slowly and calmly, each time you breathe out. As you do this, imagine that the tension throughout your body begins to melt away. To begin, clench both of your fists, and bend your elbows, drawing your forearms and hands up towards your shoulders, tightening your biceps to do so. Hold the muscles in your hands and arms tight, and notice the sensations of pulling, discomfort, and tightness. Hold the tension, while you take a deep breath into your belly, and then slowly exhale, as you release the muscles of your hands and arms. Let your hands and fingers relax completely, and let your arms become limp at your side or in your lap. Feel the sensation of relaxation, as the tension drains away from your arms and hands, and allow the muscles to become looser and looser. You may notice that they feel lighter and warmer. Breathing in slowly, and out, thinking the word "Relax" each time you breathe out. Now bring your attention to your face, and tighten your forehead, the muscles around your eyes and your jaw, by squeezing your eyes tight, clenching your jaw, and wrinkling your forehead and nose. Feel the wrinkling and pulling sensations across the forehead and the top of your head. Feel the tightness around your eyes and cheeks, and the tension in your jaw. Hold that tension, and take a deep breath into your belly, and then slowly exhale, as you let your face relax completely. Feel the muscles in your forehead becoming smooth and limp, the muscles of your cheeks and eyes softening, your jaw relaxing, let your lips part slightly, and let your jaw hang loose. Notice the tension melting away; feel your muscles becoming softer, more relaxed, and feel the warmth and lightness that replaces the tension that was there before. Contine to breathe slowly and gently, thinking the word "relax" each time you exhale. Tighten your shoulders by raising them up as if you were going to touch them to your ears, tensing without straining. Feel the tension in your shoulders radiating down into your back and up into your neck and the top of your back. Hold that. Notice those sensations and take a deep breathe into your belly, and then slowly exhale as you relax your shoulders. Let your shoulders droop down and let your neck relax completely, feeling very relaxed Notice the contrast between the tightness you felt and the relaxation you feel now. Let your head relax, as if there's nothing holding it, except the support behind it. Feel the sense of relaxation around your neck and shoulders as you let the tension drain away Continue to breathe slowly and deeply. Now bring your attention to your stomach. Tighten the muscles of your stomach by pulling your belly in towards your spine tightly. Hold that pose. Feel the sensation of the tension. Hold it while you are taking a deep breath, and then slowly exhale as you relax your muscles. Imagine a wave of relaxtion spreading through your belly. Allow the muscles of your stomach to be soft and relaxed, letting go more and more. Notice the difference the tension you felt, and the relaxation you feel now. Let any remaining tension melt away, continuing to breathe gently in and out, feeling yourself become calmer and more relaxed. Now tighten your buttocks by squeezing them together and at the same time, squeeze the muscles of your thighs. You can lift your feet up to help tense your leg muscles. Notice the sensations of tightness, pulling and constriction. Hold on to that tension, and focus on it, and take a deep breath. Then slowly exhale as you relax your buttocks and thighs. Allow your muscles to relax completely, and to let any tension drain away, melting away. Feel how the muscles of your hips and legs feel different now than they did when you were clenching them. Really notice the difference. Continue to let go further and further, experiencing an even deeper relaxation, breathing in and out, slowly and gently, in and out. Now tighten the muscles of your calves and your feet as you flex your feet, pulling your toes towards you. Flex these muscles carefully to avoid a cramp. Continue to flex your feet, feeling the muscles of your calves, feet and toes tighten and pull. Hold the tension for another second and take a deep breath. And now, slowly, exhale, release. As your muscles relax, notice how the sensations in your calves and feet change, perhaps feeling softer, or lighter. Really notice how the sensations of tension are different from the sensations your are now experiencing. With each breath, allow more tension to drain from your calves, relaxing more and more deeply. Continue to breath slowly, thinking the word "relax" each time you exhale, continuing to let any remaining tension drain away, breathing in and out, in and out. Relax, relax. Now that your whole body is feeling relaxed and comfortable, feel that sense of warmth and calmness spread over your whole body, continuing to breath naturally, smoothly and steadily, letting the breath in and out, slowly and regularly, thinking the word "relax", every time you breath out, breathing in and out, in and out. As you continue to breathe, imagine a wave of relaxation slowly spreading throughout your body. Starting at your head and gradually penetrating all of your muscles, all of the cells in your body, all the way down to your toes Allow yourself to relax completely, continuing to breathe slowly and smoothly, sinking into that feeling of relaxation and noticing how it feels so that you will be able to access it and recreate it later on your own. In a moment, I'm going to count from 5 to 1. As I do, you will gradually feel more and more alert. When I get to 3, open your eyes, and when I get to 1, you will feel alert and refreshed and ready for the rest of your day. 5, 4, beginning to shift your body, feeling a bit more awake now, 3, opening your eyes, 2, a bit more awake now, 1. Now you are feeling refreshed and alert, relaxed and ready for whatever is next.

You are about to be led through a relaxation exercise focused on visualizing something pleasant. This exercise takes about 4 minutes. It has accompanying audio, so you will have to find a quiet place or put on your headphones now.
This exercise will guide you in imagining a pleasant scene in order to reduce stress and help you relax. With this guided imagery, you can relax your muscles and breathe more deeply while you focus on a relaxing scene.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary. First, remove distractions - let others know not to bother you. Make yourself comfortable, so that your thoughts are on the image and nothing else. Sit, or lie down, in a quiet, comfortable place Then, mentally scan your body for tense muscles. If you find a muscle that tense, or clenched, relax it. During the imagery exercise, involve all of your senses in the image: sight, sound, smell, touch, and taste. Get completely focused. The more focused you are, the better. Close your eyes, or lower your gaze. In your mind's eye, you see yourself descending down a long, narrow, wooden stairway, toward a beautiful, inviting beach. Your bare feet feel the rough, weathered step. And with each step, you feel more and more tension gently melting away from your body. As you continue down the stairway, you notice the ocean is a deep shade of blue, with the fine, white crests of the waves sweeping towards the shore. You reach the end of the stairway, and step down, sinking into the warmth. As you soak in the warmth of the sun, a soothing sensation of relaxation gently melts through your entire body. The gentle sounds of the water lapping up onto the beach calm your mind, and allow you to feel even more relaxed. You begin walking slowly towards the edge of the water, and feel the warm sun on your face and shoulders. The salty smell of the ocean air invigorates you, and you take in a deep breath. Breathe slowly out, and feel more relaxed and refreshed. Finally, you reach the water's edge, and you gladly invite the little surges to flow over your toes and ankles. You watch the surges glide slowly towards you, gently sweeping around your feet, and the trails of ocean water that flows slowly back out again. The cool water feels soft and comforting, as you enjoy a few moments, allowing yourself to gaze out on the far-reaching horizon. Overhead, you notice two birds gracefully soaring high above the ocean. And you can hear their soft cries becoming faint as they glide away. All of these sights, sounds, and sensations allow you to relax and let go, more and more. After a few moments, you begin slowly strolling down the beach, at the water's edge/ You feel a warm, gentle breeze, lightly pressing against your back, and, with every step, you feel yourself relaxing, more and more. As you walk down the beach, you notice the details of sights and sounds around you, and the soothing sensations of the sun, the gentle breeze, and the sand below your feet. As you continue your leisurely walk down the beach, you notice a colorful beach chair, resting in a nice, peaceful spot, where the powdery, soft sand lies undisturbed. You approach this comfortable-looking beach chair, then you sit down, lie back, and settle in. You take in a long, deep breath, breathe slowly out, and feel even more relaxed and comfortable, resting in your chair. For a few moments more, let yourself enjoy the sights and sounds of this beautiful day on the beach. When you're ready, gently bring your attention back to the room, still letting yourself feel relaxed and comfortable, sitting where you are.

You are about to be led through a relaxation exercise focused on visualizing something pleasant. This exercise takes about 4 minutes. It has accompanying audio, so you will have to find a quiet place or put on your headphones now.
This exercise will guide you in imagining a pleasant scene in order to reduce stress and help you relax. With this guided imagery, you can relax your muscles and breathe more deeply while you focus on the relaxing scene in order to relax more deeply.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary. First, remove distractions - let others know not to bother you. Make yourself comfortable, so that your thoughts are on the image and nothing else. Sit, or lie down, in a quiet, comfortable place Mentally scan your body for tense muscles. If you find a muscle that tense, or clenched, relax it. During the imagery exercise, involve all of your senses in the image: sight, sound, smell, touch, and taste. Get completely focused. The more focused you are, the better. Close your eyes, or lower your gaze. Imagine that you are walking down a path, into a lush forest As you walk along the path, you completely take in the sights, smells, and feel of the place. All around you are trees, grasses, mossy ground cover and fragrant flowers. You hear the soothing sounds of birds chirping, and the wind as it gently blows through the treetops. You smell the rich dampness of the forest floor. The smells of moist vegetation and new growth. Through gaps in the treetops, you see the sun high in the cloudless blue sky. The sun is dispersed through the canopy of the treetops and filters down onto the forest floor, creating intricate patterns of light and shadow. With each breath you take in this place, you feel a deep sense of peace and relaxation. You soon come to a clearing. There are several flat rocks in the clearing surrounded by a soft moss. A small stream runs along the rocks. You lie back on one of the rocks, or on the cushiony moss, and put your feet into the cool water. You feel the warm sun and a gentle light breeze through your hair and across your skin. The sparkling clear water rushes around multi-colored rocks, making little whirlpools and eddies. You put your hand into the water and lift a handful to your lips. The water is cool and refreshing. You close your eyes and listen to the water trickling around the rocks. You bathe in the warm sun, and feel as though you're floating, relaxing deeper and deeper. You let yourself sink further into relaxation while continuing to be aware of the sights, smells, and feel of the forest around you. You allow yourself to let go of any concerns or worries, and to feel completely refreshed and rejuvenated in this place. When you're ready, imagine that you slowly get up and leave the clearing. As you walk back down the path through the forest, fully take in this place, and realize that you may return whenever you wish by the same path. Each time you enter this place, you will feel relaxed and at peace.

ExerciseCategory.Content:
For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 8 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start this exercise by sitting comfortably in a chair with your feet squarely on the floor. Sit with your posture firm, but not rigid. Make sure your head feels centered over your shoulders and place your arms in a comfortable position at your sides or on your lap. This posture helps you stay alert and focused. Begin by noticing that your body is sensing the environment around you. Notice that you can feel yourself sitting in your chair. Feel your feet on the ground and feel your clothes on your skin. You might feel the bend of your knees or elbows. Now, gently close your eyes, or locate a place in front of you where you can let your eyes rest, like the floor or a wall. Notice that as you close, or soften, your eyes, your ears tend to open and sound is more available to you. Take a few moments to pay attention to all of the sounds that you hear. Now gently release your attention from the sounds around you. Place your attention on the tip of your nose, and then begin to pay attention to the sensation of air moving in and out of your nostrils. Notice the change in temperature between the in breath and the out breath. Allow yourself to gently follow your breathing, paying attention to the air passing in and out of your body. You may also notice the rise and fall of your chest and belly as you breathe. Feel that expansion and contraction. Relax into your breathing, and allow it to be natural and unforced. If you become distracted by your thoughts, just take a moment to notice where the thoughts took you. Then, without judgment, let go and return your attention to your breathing. If you get distracted 100 times, that's ok - just bring yourself back to your breath 100 times. Now, take the next few minutes to attend completely to your breathing. You won't hear my voice for the next 5 minutes. Now gently release your attention from your breathing and bring your focus back to hearing. Take a moment to be aware of the sounds around you. Now, releasing your attention from sound, gently focus on the sensations in your body. Notice the placement of your feet, arms, and head. When you are ready, open and refocus your eyes. Gently begin to move and go on with your day.

For this exercise, you can walk at home, in your yard, in your neighborhood, at a park, or wherever else feels comfortable and safe to you. Try to remain silent during your walk so that you can more easily attend to your sensations and to your mind.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: about 8 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start with just standing still and noticing the sensations in your body: your feet on the ground, your balance, and where you are. Notice your breathing - the natural flow of your breath, in and out, in and out. Now, slowly begin to walk, noticing the sensations experienced by your feet as they touch the ground, sensing each part of your foot as it bends and moves as you take each step. Continue to walk slowly and as you walk, bring your full awareness to the sensations of walking, letting each foot land gently and purposefully. Notice the rhythm of your steps and how your body feels as it moves. As you walk, if your attention wanders to other things, just notice that. Then, gently bring your attention back to the experience of walking. As you walk, notice each step, feeling your feet as they meet the ground. You can also bring your attention to your legs and knees, noticing the sensations that you experience there. If you like, move your awareness to your hip area. Take time to notice the sensations you experience as you focus your attention on your hips. Remember to take your time walking, so that you can fully notice your experience and sensations. Now feel free to move your attention further up to your midsection, and allow yourself to feel all the sensations there. You can also bring your attention to your shoulders, arms, and hands. Here again, notice any sensation, movement, or rhythm in your stride. You may notice the feel of your neck and head as your feet meet the ground with each step. Now focus your attention on your head and neck. Notice any sensations that you experience in this area of your body as you move. Do you feel any difference in sensations there as you walk? Now bring your attention back to the sensations and movement of your feet as you continue to walk. If you notice that you are starting to walk more quickly, slow your pace to become more aware of every aspect of the experience of taking a step. Continue to walk for as long as you like. When you are finished, stand for a moment and bring your attention to your breath, noticing how your chest and belly naturally rise and fall as you breathe.

For this exercise, you will need three raisins or other small fruits, such as berries or cherries. Then, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you will be able to focus on this mindfulness exercise.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: about 6 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start this exercise by sitting comfortably in a chair with your feet squarely on the floor. Sit with your posture firm, but not rigid. Make sure your head feels centered over your shoulders, and place your arms in a comfortable position. This posture helps you stay alert and focused. When we eat, we tend to put food into our mouths without much thought. You might be amazed to discover how much deeper your experience of eating a small piece of fruit can be if you treat it mindfully. First, take a raisin or another small piece of fruit, and eat it the way you normally do, that is, just pop it into your mouth, chew, and swallow. Now, get another one of that same kind of fruit. Place it in front of you and examine it. Notice any wrinkles, and the texture of its skin. Notice where it is smooth, rough, or furry, and the various shapes any wrinkles or bumps may form. Now take out another piece of fruit and place it next to the first, and notice how unalike they are. No two pieces of fruit are identical. Are these two fruits the same size? Think about the fruits in term of the space they take up in the room, in the world, and in the universe. Think about their size in relation to each other, as well. Now pick up one of the fruits and roll it around between your fingers. Feel the texture on the outside of the fruit. Feel any sticky or moist traces it leaves on your fingers. Place the fruit in your mouth. Roll it around inside your mouth, over and under your tongue. Hide it in the crevices between your jaws and your cheeks. Don't chew it for at least 30 seconds or so. When you are ready, slowly eat the fruit and notice the way it tastes. Note the way it feels on your teeth as you chew, and how it feels as you swallow. When you are ready, eat the second piece of fruit, but this time, eat it really slowly. Chew the fruit as many times as you can, until it turns into mush in your mouth, and then swallow. Is the flavor different when it is eaten this way than it was last time? How is it different? What does it feel like in your mouth as it falls apart? How does it feel as you finally swallow it? How does it compare with the first piece of fruit? What's different when you eat the fruit mindfully rather than simply popping it in your mouth and slurping it down? When you are finished, sit or stand for a moment and bring your attention to your breath, noticing how your chest and belly naturally rise and fall as you breathe, before you go on with your day.

For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 10 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start this exercise by sitting comfortably in a chair with your feet squarely on the floor. Sit with your posture firm, but not rigid. Make sure your head feels centered over your shoulders and place your arms in a comfortable position at your sides or on your lap. This posture helps you stay alert and focused. Now, gently close your eyes, or locate a place in front of you where you can let your eyes rest, like the floor or a wall. Gently bring your attention to the natural rhythm of your breathing. Simply notice your breath as you inhale and exhale. You may notice the breath coming in and out through your nostrils, or you may focus on the sensations in your chest and belly rising and falling as you breathe. There is no need to make the breath faster or slower, deeper or shallower. Just allow breathing to happen. Simply allow the natural pace of your breathing as you continue to pay attention. Now imagine that you are sitting next to a small stream on warm autumn day. As you gaze at the stream, you notice a number of large leaves of varying colors and shapes drifting along, each at its own pace, one by one, in the slowly moving current. Allow yourself to simply be with this scene for a moment, observing. Now, gradually bring your awareness to what's going on inside you - thoughts, sensations, feelings, desires, impulses. Now, bring your attention particularly to what's happening in your mind. As you do, gently notice the thoughts that show up. You may notice judgments, plans, and memories, fantasies, resentments, worries, and other thoughts. Notice all your thoughts with an attitude of compassionate allowing. Bring the stream back to your awareness. As thoughts come into your mind, notice them, and gently place them one by one on each large leaf passing by in the stream. Observe each leaf as it comes closer to you. Then watch as it moves away, drifting along and carrying that thought out of sight downstream. Return to gazing at the stream, waiting for the next leaf to float by. Continue placing each thought on its own large leaf. Observe each one as you let it float away downstream. When you are ready to end this exercise, shift your attention to the sounds around you. Then shift your attention to your breath, and the rise and fall of your chest and belly as you inhale and exhale. Now picture what the room you are in looks like, and when you are ready, open, or refocus, your eyes and look around. Take your time before you go on with your day.

For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed. This mindfulness exercise will help you practice mindfulness of physical sensations.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 10 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start this exercise by finding a comfortable position sitting in a chair, or lying on a bed or the floor. Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths. Relax. Don't let yourself drift off to sleep during this exercise, but allow yourself to rest. Now slowly bring your awareness to the tips of your fingers. Feel your fingers. Now, rub your fingertips together. How do they feel? Can you feel the small indentations on that are your fingerprints? Take your time and try to feel them. What do they feel like? Are your fingertips raw from lots of work or are they smooth? How does it feel to rub them together? Notice the sensations. Now rest your fingers where they were before. What are they touching? Are they resting on a blanket, on the arms of your chair, on your legs or stomach, or something else? What does that feel like? Is it soft or hard? Does it have any other distinguishing features or textures? Take the time to completely absorb the way these objects feel to your fingertips. Now bring attention to your hands and arms. What do they feel like? Perhaps they are relaxed and heavy. Perhaps they are tense from work or stress. Either way is okay. There is no need to judge; simply observe the feelings in your arms and hands. Are there any aches or pains? Take note of these, but don't fixate on them. Simply notice the pain and move on. Move your attention down to your toes now. Wiggle them around a little. Are they in shoes or socks? Are they free to move about? Wiggle them and notice whatever is around or under them. Do you notice air, or the feeling of blankets or socks? Be aware of the experience. Just notice the sensations as you bring your awareness to your feet. Now shift your attention, and notice how your head is positioned. Is it upright or tilted? Is your head turned in a particular direction? Simply notice your head's positioning without trying to change it. Also notice any sensations that you are experiencing in your head or neck, such as tension or relaxation. Take your time noticing. What about your face? How does your face feel? There are all kinds of sensations to explore here. Think about your brow. Is it smooth and flat or is it wrinkled up with stress? Again, don't try to change it, just notice it. Now bring awareness to your nose. Can you breathe freely? Take a few breaths in and out through your nose. Can you feel air flowing into your nose? Is the air warm or cool? Pay attention to these feelings for a moment. Then think about your mouth. How is it positioned? Is it pursed? Open? Closed? What about the inside of your mouth? Is it wet or dry? Explore all of the sensations throughout your face. Perhaps your skin feels dry, or you notice other sensations of itching, tingling, heaviness, heat, or coolness. Perhaps there is no feeling at all. Just notice. Now bring your attention to your chest and belly. Place one hand on your chest and one hand on your belly. Can you feel your body breathing? What is that like? Are you breathing fast or slow? Is your breath going more into your belly or your chest? Now breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth. How does that feel? Now invert that pattern, breathing in through your mouth and out through your nose, and notice how that feels. Now breathe naturally, just noticing the sensations. Next place your hands wherever they were before and expand your attention to include your whole body. Where are you sitting or lying? Can you feel the back side of your body touching the chair or bed in various places? Be mindful of the way your body is positioned. There is no need to move, just observe. Now, with your eyes still closed, imagine the room you're in. Where are you positioned in the room? Do you have a sense of where the door is? What about the ceiling? Can you feel your body in the larger space? When you are ready, open your eyes and look around the room. You can move if you wish. Notice where the various pieces of furniture and decoration are. What do they look like? You can spend as much time as you like investigating different aspects of the room. Remember not to judge, just to notice. Whenever you are ready, you can stop this exercise and continue with your day.

For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 9 minutes.

Use this exercise to practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Please do not do this exercise while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise. Turn up your volume now if necessary.
Start this exercise by sitting comfortably in a chair with your feet squarely on the floor and your posture firm, but not rigid. Make sure your head feels centered over your shoulders and place your arms in a comfortable position at your sides or on your lap. Now, gently close your eyes, or locate a place in front of you where you can let your eyes rest, like the floor or a wall. Take a few moments to get in touch with the physical sensations in your body, especially the sensations of touch or pressure where your body makes contact with the chair or floor. Notice the rising and falling of your breath in your chest and belly. There is no need to control your breathing in any way, simply allow yourself to breathe naturally. As best you can, bring this gentle attitude of allowing to all of your experience. There is nothing to be fixed. Simply let your experience to be your experience, without needing it to be anything other than what it is. Now allow yourself to become aware of what you are afraid of or uncomfortable about. Notice any doubts, frustrations, fears, upsets and worries. Just notice them and acknowledge their presence. Don't try to work on, resolve, or address them. As you simply notice your concerns, pause, andalso allow yourself to be present to your values and commitments. Ask yourself, "What matters to me?" "What is important to me?" When you're ready, gently shift your focus to a single thought or situation that has been difficult for you. It could be a troubling thought, worry, image, or body sensation. Gently and firmly shift your attention toward that discomfort, no matter how bad it seems. Notice any desire or urge to avoid it. Notice any strong feelings that arise in your body. Allow those feelings to be as they are. Simply hold them in awareness, as you stay with your discomfort and breathe with it. See if you can gently open up to it and make space for it. Accept and allow it to be as it is, while bringing compassionate and focused attention to the discomfort. If you notice yourself tensing up and resisting, pushing away from the experience, just acknowledge that and see if you can make some space for whatever you're experiencing. Must this feeling or thought be your enemy? Or can you have it, notice it, and let it be? Can you make room for the discomfort, for the tension? What does it really feel like, moment to moment, to have all of this experience? Is this something you must struggle with, or can you invite the discomfort in, saying to yourself, "let me feel what there is to be felt because it is my experience right now."? If the sensations or discomfort grow stronger, acknowledge that and stay with them, breathing with them and accepting them. Can you bring openness to it, make space for it? Is there room inside you to feel that, with compassion and kindness towards yourself and your experience? As you open up and embrace your experience you may notice your thoughts. When that happens, invite them in too, opening to them as you become aware of them. You may also notice your mind coming up with judgmental labels such as "dangerous" or "getting worse." If that happens, you can simply thank your mind for the label and return to the present experience as it actually is, not as your minds says it is, noticing thoughts as thoughts, physical sensations as physical sensations, feelings as feelings - nothing more, nothing less. Stay with your discomfort for as long as it pulls on your attention. If and when you sense that the discomfort is no longer pulling for your attention, let it go. As you feel the time for practice coming to a close, you can gradually widen your attention to take in the sounds around you. Then slowly open, or refocus, your eyes. Take your time before you go on with your day.
