Content.title: Use Technology
Content.Content:
Using your phone for daily activities

Your smartphone has features that can help organize your everyday life and accomplish things you need or wish to do. Using these features may make it easier to keep up with daily activities and help with your recovery.

If you are very good at finding your way around the smartphone, you can try using the features described on your own. If setting up the smartphone does not come easily, or you are wondering how you can use the features most effectively, you can try working with a healthcare professional, usually a speech pathologist or an occupational therapist, who can customize the smartphone functions for your needs.

Calendar

The calendar app on your phone is helpful for making a daily schedule and setting up your appointments for the future. Enter all the information that will allow you to remember the reason for the appointment, such as the name of the person or place, location, and phone number to call. Make sure that the appointment does not overlap with another commitment you have made for the same time slot.

You can also set up reminders that will alert you well in advance of when an appointment is coming up. This will allow you to make all the preparations you need to get there on time.

Other calendar apps may have additional features to help you organize your schedule, such as assigning icons or colors to appointments, attaching pictures, linking with a social networking site, or syncing with a web site calendar service.

Reminders and Alarms

The reminders app on your phone is a great way to create reminders for yourself if you notice having trouble with memory, or if you want to keep yourself on a sleep schedule. Create descriptive names and use different alert tones for your reminders to help you stick to the routine you want, without having to worry about forgetting things.

You can set reminders to repeat at the same time every day, or to activate when your phone's GPS detects that you are at a certain location. Additionally, in your phone's settings you can customize the notification alerts you receive from many other apps, such as when you receive a text message or a phone call.

Other alarm apps may have additional features to help you customize your reminders, such as additional repeat options, more alert tones, or the ability to attach a photo or voice memo.

Timer

Timer/stopwatch apps can be used to assist with taking appropriate breaks. Use the timer to allow some time for exercise or relaxing activities. Or use it to help you manage multiple projects at once, such as cooking while engaging in another activity.

Other timer apps may have additional features, such as a visual display of time elapsed or time remaining, the ability to run more than one timer at once, or a counter for the number of times you've taken a break.

Contacts List

The contacts app is a great place to find support or get in touch with friends and family when low mood, frustration or irritability is bringing you down. A quick call or a short text can lift your spirits and make the day seem a bit more manageable.

Other contacts apps may have additional features, such as displaying contacts by their photos, sorting people into groups or lists, or linking to a social networking site.

Notes and Lists

Use the note-taking or list apps on your phone to jot down ideas or lists of things you'd like to accomplish. Not only will this help you remember things you need to do, it will assist with focusing on one task at a time.

If you're finding yourself having trouble remembering something or focusing, jot down a note about what it is you need to do. If you're anxious or frustrated, summarize your goal; taking a moment to think about the big picture might help you not sweat the small stuff. If you have trouble getting organized for work, prepare a to-do list in the evening related to getting ready to leave for work.

Other note-taking or list apps may have additional features, such as multiple notebooks or lists, the ability to attach a photo, voice memo, or map, syncing to your computer, or sharing with friends.

The voice recorder app is another way to make notes to yourself. If you prefer talking to typing on your phone screen, or often have your hands full, this may work better for you. Recording memos can help you remember ideas, list things to do, save a class lecture so you can focus on it later, or relieve stress by talking about something that's troubling you.

There are many free and low-price voice recorder apps you can add to your phone to have another way to make notes to yourself. If you prefer talking to typing on your phone screen, or often have your hands full, this may work better for you. Recording memos can help you remember ideas, list things to do, save a class lecture so you can focus on it later, or relieve stress by talking about something that's troubling you.

Some recorder apps may have additional features, such as editing your memos, syncing to your computer, or transcription.

Maps

The maps app uses GPS to guide you in case you lose your way to your next destination. Type in the address or a nearby landmark to find your way if you get confused. You can also enter keywords (like "coffee shop") to find a place nearby to relax and reset.

Some map apps may have additional features, such as saving favorite locations or spoken directions.

Music and Podcasts

Load music or podcasts onto your smartphone so you have them within reach if you need a quick way to relax. Listening to peaceful or soothing tunes may take your mind off anxiety, reduce frustration or help sleep come more quickly.

Podcasts can also be entertaining and a great way to learn about anything under the sun. Most of them are free from the music store on your smartphone.

Camera and Photos

The camera app can be used to take pictures of new places, co-workers, or any other person or thing you want to remember. You can also take pictures of receipts or notes jotted on paper to reduce clutter.

Choose calming or inspiring photos from your library to help improve your mood or reduce frustration. Looking at peaceful scenes or reflecting on happy memories may improve your focus and help you relax.

Web Browser

Use your web browser to search for pretty much any information you need. While memory lapses may be frustrating, having a smartphone can be a tremendous help when you use it to retrieve a forgotten address or access some information that slipped your mind.

You can add useful web sites to your bookmarks, add sites directly to the home screen of your phone, or email a web link to yourself.

Other apps

You can download many other apps to help you focus your time better, track daily habits, organize housework, fall asleep to white noise, connect with friends, or find more things to do nearby.

Most apps are available for a very low cost or for free, so it’s easy to try an app to decide how well it works for you.

iStressLess.Content:
The self-assessment in this app is called the Neurobehavioral Symptom Inventory (NSI).This scale has been used with people who had a concussion to assess the effects of the concussion symptoms on their daily living.

Even if you did not have a concussion or your symptoms are not likely to be related to the concussion, the self-assessment can help you keep track of how the effects of the symptoms on your daily living change as a result of using the tools in this app.

When answering the questions, the choices mean:

  • None - Rarely if ever present; not a problem at all
  • Mild - Occasionally present, but it does not disrupt activities; I can usually continue what I'm doing; doesn't really concern me.
  • Moderate - Often present, occasionally disrupts my activities; I can usually continue what I'm doing with some effort; I feel somewhat concerned.
  • Severe - Frequently present and disrupts activities; I can only do things that are fairly simple or take little effort; I feel like I need help.
  • Very Severe - Almost always present and I have been unable to perform at work, school or home due to this problem; I probably cannot function without help.

These exercises are simple strategies to help distract and detach from current problems, and reconnect in the present to the world around you. The grounding strategies in each section are geared specifically for the symptom you selected.
These quotes may offer inspiration and new perspectives to help you move forward in a positive way.

This exercise allows you to take a break from a situation that is upsetting you (or someone else) before you do something you'll regret. A time out is a time-limited break (often 10-15 minutes) that helps people manage their anger, anxiety, or confusion so that they can resolve their problems more effectively. The time out exercise offers more instructions and guidance on how and when to take a time out, and what to do to help yourself during your time out.

These strategies include tips for falling asleep right now, as well as advice for managing insomnia so that you can fall asleep more easily on a regular basis. These strategies, along with some of the relaxation exercises in this app, can help you relax and sleep better.

This exercise will guide you in doing enjoyable activities in order to increase the amount of pleasure in your life. Especially if you're feeling down, it can be hard to get motivated to do the things that would usually be fun or give you a feeling of accomplishment. However, research shows that making an effort to do these things even when you don't feel like it can ultimately improve your mood.

The Change Your Perspective tools provide reminders that can help give you hope and confidence. We all have a constant stream of thoughts running through our minds — this is called self-talk. Negative self-talk, like believing that things are terrible or that the worst is about to happen can stress your body and make your symptoms worse. These positive self-talk reminders give you something you can hold on to; they can help you think more realistically, and may even help you manage situations more effectively.

This activity will guide you in reaching out for support. Reaching out for support can be difficult when you're feeling down or upset; however, having good support is strongly related to improved mood and mental health, and may be an important part of your recovery from trauma.

These are suggested activities to help you distract yourself from overwhelming emotions and the situations that may be triggering them. Distracting yourself may not completely make your feelings go away, but it can make surviving them a little easier.
